factoid: The speaker says they cannot hold all that line.
The speaker says it is impossible.
The speaker will undertake to break through.
The speaker says that with five hundred men he will break the line.
The speaker says there is only one way—guerrilla warfare.
Denisov rose.
Denisov gesticulated.
Denisov explained his plan to Bolkonski.
Shouts were heard from the army during Denisov's explanation.
The shouts grew more incoherent and diffused.
Music and songs mingled with the shouts.
The shouts came from the field where the review was held.
Hooves and shouts were heard near the village.
A Cossack at the gate shouted "He's coming!" twice.
Bolkonski and Denisov moved to the gate.
A guard of honor was standing at the gate.
Kutuzov came down the street on a small sorrel horse.
A large group of generals rode behind Kutuzov.
Barclay rode almost beside Kutuzov.
Officers shouted "Hurrah!" while running after the group.
Kutuzov's adjutants galloped into the yard before him.
Kutuzov urged his horse impatiently.
Kutuzov raised his hand to his white Horse Guard's cap with a red band and no peak.
Kutuzov nodded his head continually.
Kutuzov approached the guard of honor.
The guard of honor was a fine set of Grenadiers mostly wearing decorations.
The Grenadiers were giving Kutuzov a salute.
Kutuzov looked at the Grenadiers silently and attentively for nearly a minute.
Kutuzov turned to the crowd of generals and officers.
Kutuzov's face assumed a subtle expression.
Kutuzov shrugged his shoulders with an air of perplexity.
Kutuzov said "And with such fine fellows to retreat and retreat! Well, good‑by, General."
Kutuzov rode into the yard past Prince Andrew and Denisov.
Those behind Kutuzov shouted "Hurrah! hurrah! hurrah!"
Since Prince Andrew last saw Kutuzov, Kutuzov had become more corpulent, flaccid, and fat.
Kutuzov's bleached eyeball, scar, and familiar weariness were still the same.
Kutuzov wore the white Horse Guard's cap.
Kutuzov wore a military overcoat.
Kutuzov had a whip hanging over his shoulder by a thin strap.
Kutuzov sat heavily and swayed limply on his brisk little horse.
Kutuzov whistled "Whew... whew... whew!" as he rode into the yard.
Kutuzov's face expressed relief of relaxed strain after a ceremony.
Kutuzov drew his left foot out of the stirrup.
Kutuzov lurching with his whole body and puckering his face, raised his left foot onto the saddle.
Kutuzov leaned on his knee.
Kutuzov groaned.
Kutuzov slipped down into the arms of the Cossacks and adjutants ready to assist him.
Kutuzov pulled himself together.
Kutuzov looked around.
Kutuzov glanced at Prince Andrew.
Kutuzov did not recognize Prince Andrew.
Kutuzov moved with his waddling gait to the porch.
Kutuzov whistled "Whew... whew... whew!" again and glanced at Prince Andrew.
After some seconds, Kutuzov recognized Prince Andrew's face.
Kutuzov said "Ah, how do you do, my dear prince? How do you do, my dear boy? Come along..."
Kutuzov glanced wearily round.
Kutuzov stepped onto the porch which creaked under his weight.
Kutuzov unbuttoned his coat.
Kutuzov sat down on a bench in the porch.
Prince Andrew asked "And how’s your father?"
Prince Andrew replied that he received news of his father's death yesterday.
Kutuzov looked at Prince Andrew with eyes wide open and dismay.
Kutuzov took off his cap and crossed himself.
Kutuzov said "May the kingdom of Heaven be his! God's will be done to us all!"
Kutuzov sighed deeply.
Kutuzov's chest heaved.
Kutuzov was silent for a while.
Kutuzov said "I loved him and respected him, and sympathize with you with all my heart."
Kutuzov embraced Prince Andrew, pressing him to his fat breast.
Kutuzov did not let Prince Andrew go for some time.
Kutuzov's flabby lips were trembling.
Kutuzov had tears in his eyes.
Kutuzov sighed.
Kutuzov pressed on the bench with both hands to raise himself.
Kutuzov said "Come! Come with me, we’ll have a talk."
